channel.title: Best Operating System
channel.description: Hey! Just want to throw this discussion out there. What do you think the best recent (last 10 years) operating system is? If you have one not on the list I should add just say it.

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch2 Java Is My Bitch
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“faded vision, post:78, topic:345055”]Undoubtedly Ubuntu or Linux, but I use windows 7 on my main computer because its more user friendly.

Although I do use Ubuntu over Windows for any VPS’s I own because of its efficiency in comparison.[/quote]Ubuntu is Linux.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch, post:64, topic:345055”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=441433.msg3245338#msg3245338 date=1277310268]

[quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=441433.msg3245333#msg3245333 date=1277309766]

Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.

Linux, at least with KDE, has far more features that Windows 7, it also had that much advertised ‘snap’ feature before Windows 7 came out. Also, what do you mean by ‘compatibility’? Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.

different type of compatibility.

lets say 100,000 programs are out there.

i would say 99.9% of them were made for windows, and even then that 0.1 can still run on windows. Sure linux can run some of them with 3rd party programs and even then with glitches etc, it’s just not the same.

I have tried Linux and i know MITB your a big Linux fanboy, but really how can you say windows is not the best OS overall. a computer is nothing without a wide range of things to do. Windows achieves that simply because it has the market share, and since developers like to get their apps sold, almost everything is made for windows.

Same goes with hardware really, in Windows you can plug and play non legacy hardware and there’s a good chance it would run straight off the bat. If it does not, you can get drivers from the manufacturer to do that. Theres a very small chance these driver packages will be set up for anything other than windows.

With linux you need to spend hours tracking down the right drivers to get all your gear working, and even then your bound to come across problems. With windows it is much simpler, that’s just how it is.

we can put on a huge windows vs linux debate if you wanna go that far, im sure linux suits your needs and all, i know it sucks that windows cost money and M$ are cunts, but windows simply is the best OS.
[/quote]Really, you just need to give other operating systems a chance, I used to be a Windows fanboy but then I switched to Linux. At first I was like “Umm, this is bullshit.” then I messed around with the settings, installed some programs that increased compatibility, and I fucking loved it. And I’ve gotta say that the fact that it rarely crashed was a huge plus up. Later on I got a Mac and it’s just about the same except with better graphical interfaces.

if i was just a programmer sure id use linux, but i’m a heavy gamer. that cuts my choices down to windows. plus i’m quite a master in windows after all these years, i like being able to find my way around in seconds, and not have to use effort figuring out how to do stuff in linux.

i’m a man who likes tasks completed in as little time, and as easy as possible, which is why i’m Windows only.
[/quote]Yea, but when you get a virus, or your programs crash you have to start over and/or lose time.
Both ways you’ll lose time in the long run.[/quote]

nah, IMO advanced windows user will always have the fastest route.

Read full topic

item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

Vista cause i dont really use other OS’s in my household; although i have a Windows 7 installed PC and Laptop.
XP Pro is proberly the most stable Windows OS, not sure if Win7 is better.

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch2 Java Is My Bitch
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:62, topic:345055”][quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=441433.msg3245333#msg3245333 date=1277309766]

Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.

Linux, at least with KDE, has far more features that Windows 7, it also had that much advertised ‘snap’ feature before Windows 7 came out. Also, what do you mean by ‘compatibility’? Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.

different type of compatibility.

lets say 100,000 programs are out there.

i would say 99.9% of them were made for windows, and even then that 0.1 can still run on windows. Sure linux can run some of them with 3rd party programs and even then with glitches etc, it’s just not the same.

I have tried Linux and i know MITB your a big Linux fanboy, but really how can you say windows is not the best OS overall. a computer is nothing without a wide range of things to do. Windows achieves that simply because it has the market share, and since developers like to get their apps sold, almost everything is made for windows.

Same goes with hardware really, in Windows you can plug and play non legacy hardware and there’s a good chance it would run straight off the bat. If it does not, you can get drivers from the manufacturer to do that. Theres a very small chance these driver packages will be set up for anything other than windows.

With linux you need to spend hours tracking down the right drivers to get all your gear working, and even then your bound to come across problems. With windows it is much simpler, that’s just how it is.

we can put on a huge windows vs linux debate if you wanna go that far, im sure linux suits your needs and all, i know it sucks that windows cost money and M$ are cunts, but windows simply is the best OS.
[/quote]Really, you just need to give other operating systems a chance, I used to be a Windows fanboy but then I switched to Linux. At first I was like “Umm, this is bullshit.” then I messed around with the settings, installed some programs that increased compatibility, and I fucking loved it. And I’ve gotta say that the fact that it rarely crashed was a huge plus up. Later on I got a Mac and it’s just about the same except with better graphical interfaces.

if i was just a programmer sure id use linux, but i’m a heavy gamer. that cuts my choices down to windows. plus i’m quite a master in windows after all these years, i like being able to find my way around in seconds, and not have to use effort figuring out how to do stuff in linux.

i’m a man who likes tasks completed in as little time, and as easy as possible, which is why i’m Windows only.[/quote]Yea, but when you get a virus, or your programs crash you have to start over and/or lose time.
Both ways you’ll lose time in the long run.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

I don’t see why we have to only like 1 OP, I feel like people try to only say one OP is the best when there really is no best they all counter each other to the point where they have about the same different features.

Linux - Stable, open source, big community that helps, easy to learn and use, etc.
Windows - so what stable, very compatible, easy to learn, etc.
MAC - stable?, compatible, very good graphical stuff and other nice entertainment stuff, etc.

We should be choosing the best out of each OP, because it would be impossible to pick the best because you have to also add in how much it is used, cost, what other features are added in like service packets (Updates), etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch, post:61, topic:345055”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=441433.msg3245322#msg3245322 date=1277309263]

Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.

Linux, at least with KDE, has far more features that Windows 7, it also had that much advertised ‘snap’ feature before Windows 7 came out. Also, what do you mean by ‘compatibility’? Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.

different type of compatibility.

lets say 100,000 programs are out there.

i would say 99.9% of them were made for windows, and even then that 0.1 can still run on windows. Sure linux can run some of them with 3rd party programs and even then with glitches etc, it’s just not the same.

I have tried Linux and i know MITB your a big Linux fanboy, but really how can you say windows is not the best OS overall. a computer is nothing without a wide range of things to do. Windows achieves that simply because it has the market share, and since developers like to get their apps sold, almost everything is made for windows.

Same goes with hardware really, in Windows you can plug and play non legacy hardware and there’s a good chance it would run straight off the bat. If it does not, you can get drivers from the manufacturer to do that. Theres a very small chance these driver packages will be set up for anything other than windows.

With linux you need to spend hours tracking down the right drivers to get all your gear working, and even then your bound to come across problems. With windows it is much simpler, that’s just how it is.

we can put on a huge windows vs linux debate if you wanna go that far, im sure linux suits your needs and all, i know it sucks that windows cost money and M$ are cunts, but windows simply is the best OS.
[/quote]Really, you just need to give other operating systems a chance, I used to be a Windows fanboy but then I switched to Linux. At first I was like “Umm, this is bullshit.” then I messed around with the settings, installed some programs that increased compatibility, and I fucking loved it. And I’ve gotta say that the fact that it rarely crashed was a huge plus up. Later on I got a Mac and it’s just about the same except with better graphical interfaces.[/quote]
if i was just a programmer sure id use linux, but i’m a heavy gamer. that cuts my choices down to windows. plus i’m quite a master in windows after all these years, i like being able to find my way around in seconds, and not have to use effort figuring out how to do stuff in linux.

i’m a man who likes tasks completed in as little time, and as easy as possible, which is why i’m Windows only.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:60, topic:345055”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=441433.msg3245270#msg3245270 date=1277305840]

Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.

Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.
[/quote]

different type of compatibility.

lets say 100,000 programs are out there.

i would say 99.9% of them were made for windows, and even then that 0.1 can still run on windows. Sure linux can run some of them with 3rd party programs and even then with glitches etc, it’s just not the same.

I have tried Linux and i know MITB your a big Linux fanboy, but really how can you say windows is not the best OS overall. a computer is nothing without a wide range of things to do. Windows achieves that simply because it has the market share, and since developers like to get their apps sold, almost everything is made for windows.

Same goes with hardware really, in Windows you can plug and play non legacy hardware and there’s a good chance it would run straight off the bat. If it does not, you can get drivers from the manufacturer to do that. Theres a very small chance these driver packages will be set up for anything other than windows.

With linux you need to spend hours tracking down the right drivers to get all your gear working, and even then your bound to come across problems. With windows it is much simpler, that’s just how it is.

we can put on a huge windows vs linux debate if you wanna go that far, im sure linux suits your needs and all, i know it sucks that windows cost money and M$ are cunts, but windows simply is the best OS.[/quote]Really, you just need to give other operating systems a chance, I used to be a Windows fanboy but then I switched to Linux. At first I was like “Umm, this is bullshit.” then I messed around with the settings, installed some programs that increased compatibility, and I fucking loved it. And I’ve gotta say that the fact that it rarely crashed was a huge plus up. Later on I got a Mac and it’s just about the same except with better graphical interfaces.

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:58, topic:345055”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=441433.msg3244993#msg3244993 date=1277277534]
Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.
[/quote]

Linux, at least with KDE, has far more features that Windows 7, it also had that much advertised ‘snap’ feature before Windows 7 came out. Also, what do you mean by ‘compatibility’? Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.[/quote]

different type of compatibility.

lets say 100,000 programs are out there.

i would say 99.9% of them were made for windows, and even then that 0.1 can still run on windows. Sure linux can run some of them with 3rd party programs and even then with glitches etc, it’s just not the same.

I have tried Linux and i know MITB your a big Linux fanboy, but really how can you say windows is not the best OS overall. a computer is nothing without a wide range of things to do. Windows achieves that simply because it has the market share, and since developers like to get their apps sold, almost everything is made for windows.

Same goes with hardware really, in Windows you can plug and play non legacy hardware and there’s a good chance it would run straight off the bat. If it does not, you can get drivers from the manufacturer to do that. Theres a very small chance these driver packages will be set up for anything other than windows.

With linux you need to spend hours tracking down the right drivers to get all your gear working, and even then your bound to come across problems. With windows it is much simpler, that’s just how it is.

we can put on a huge windows vs linux debate if you wanna go that far, im sure linux suits your needs and all, i know it sucks that windows cost money and M$ are cunts, but windows simply is the best OS.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Operating System
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch2 Java Is My Bitch
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:56, topic:345055”][quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=441433.msg3245202#msg3245202 date=1277302404]

Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.
[/quote]Mac OSX is also very complex and it can run on 1 GB of ram. (with no problems at all.)
[/quote]mac is the worst out of them all. AFAIK It only has compatibility for it’s specified hardware that mac’s use. Therefore it lacks hardware and software compatibility.[/quote]Actually, all you have to do is get crossover and you can run any windows program, and hardware wise, I think it may be worth it.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:58, topic:345055”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=441433.msg3244993#msg3244993 date=1277277534]
Windows 7. it is very fast for the amount of features & complexity it has, it also has the highest compatibility out of any operating system.

Linux, at least with KDE, has far more features that Windows 7, it also had that much advertised ‘snap’ feature before Windows 7 came out. Also, what do you mean by ‘compatibility’? Windows 7 obviously has more compatibility with windows programs, but Linux has more compatibility with Linux programs etc etc. So even with software compatibility, windows has no way to run linux programs, but on linux you can use WINE to run some windows programs.

If you are talking about hardware compatibility, then you are just plain wrong. Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.[/quote] Yea. Kubuntu is pretty powerful but I think that it’s a little not-user friendly. But yea I think Ubuntu is the best for minimal memory usage.

Read full topic

Windows only runs on x86 or amd64 architectures, Linux runs on a vast majority of architectures and devices that range from personal computers, netbooks, smart phones and ‘dumb’ phones, servers, super computers, cars, toasters, microwaves, satellite boxes, cable boxes, and VOIP phones like skype.
